g.text: Cl was studied by AIMD simulations at simulated
temperatures ranging from 300 K to 1400 K with an increment of 50 K. To monitor the changes of
the structure with increasing temperature, we calculated the pair distribution function (PDF),
which gives the probability of ﬁnding a

is the length of a vector connecting atom
and Al–O at various temperatures. The three relatively sharp peaks for both
400 K correspond to the atomic distances between the nearest, second, and third nearest neighbors of
O atoms around Li and Al, respectively, in LiAl
Cl, as expected. All three peaks of both
get broader in peak width and lower in intensity with increasing temperature, indicating
that the Li–O and Al–O interactions become weaker at high temperatures. Due to the lower charge
of Li compared to Al, the changes for
positions remain nearly unchanged in our simulations. In contrast, the situation is di

a). It is worth mentioning that in the
curve at 400 K, the ﬁrst, second,
and third nearest neighbor Li–O distances are still well deﬁned, whereas at higher temperatures,
the peaks are smeared out, indicating a higher dynamics of the Li atoms. This demonstrates that
octahedral coordination around the Li atoms is not regular any more above 600 K. A similar situation
was found in experiments by Hou and Kirkpatrick [
which gives the probability of finding a
is the volume of the system, and
is the length of a vector connecting atom
. Figure 3 shows the PDF of Li–
O and Al–O at various temperatures. The three relatively sharp peaks for both
at 400 K correspond to the atomic distances between the nearest, second, and third nearest neighbors
of O atoms around Li and Al, respectively, in LiAl
Cl, as expected. All three peaks of both
get broader in peak width and lower in intensity with increasing temperature,
indicating that the Li–O and Al–O interactions become weaker at high temperatures. Due to the lower
charge of Li compared to Al, the changes for
the peak positions remain nearly unchanged in our simulations. In contrast, the situation is different
, where the Li–O distance of around ~2.0 Å, indicated by the first peak contracts slightly
with the increase of the temperature (Figure 3a). It is worth mentioning that in the
400 K, the first, second, and third nearest neighbor Li–O distances are still well defined, whereas at
higher temperatures, the peaks are smeared out, indicating a higher dynamics of the Li atoms. This
demonstrates that octahedral coordination around the Li atoms is not regular any more above 600 K.
A similar situation was found in experiments by Hou and Kirkpatrick [23], where the decomposition
of LiAl-LDH began at temperatures slightly below 573 K.

corresponding to the tail of the ﬁrst peak in the PDF.
shows the evolution of the PCN with an increasing temperature for Li–O and Al–O.
